segment.source: DeviceUseTrigger lets your Universal Windows app access sensors and peripheral devices in the background, even when your foreground app is suspended.
segment.target: DeviceUseTrigger lets your Universal Windows app access sensors and peripheral devices in the background, even when your foreground app is suspended.

segment.source: For example, depending on where your app is running, it could use a background task to synchronize data with devices or monitor sensors.
segment.target: For example, depending on where your app is running, it could use a background task to synchronize data with devices or monitor sensors.

segment.source: To help preserve battery life and ensure the appropriate user consent, the use of DeviceUseTrigger is subject to policies that are described in this topic.
segment.target: To help preserve battery life and ensure the appropriate user consent, the use of DeviceUseTrigger is subject to policies that are described in this topic.

segment.source: To access sensors or peripheral devices in the background, create a background task that uses the DeviceUseTrigger.
segment.target: To access sensors or peripheral devices in the background, create a background task that uses the DeviceUseTrigger.

segment.source: For an example that shows how this is done on a PC, see the Custom USB device sample.
segment.target: For an example that shows how this is done on a PC, see the Custom USB device sample.

segment.source: For an example on a phone, see the Background Sensors sample.
segment.target: For an example on a phone, see the Background Sensors sample.

segment.source: Device background task overview
segment.target: Device background task overview

segment.source: When your app is no longer visible to the user, Windows will suspend or terminate your app to reclaim memory and CPU resources.
segment.target: When your app is no longer visible to the user, Windows will suspend or terminate your app to reclaim memory and CPU resources.

segment.source: This allows other apps to run in the foreground and reduces battery consumption.
segment.target: This allows other apps to run in the foreground and reduces battery consumption.

segment.source: When this happens, without the help of a background task, any ongoing data events will be lost.
segment.target: When this happens, without the help of a background task, any ongoing data events will be lost.

segment.source: Windows provides the background task trigger, DeviceUseTrigger, to let your app perform long running sync and monitoring operations on devices and sensors safely in the background, even if your app is suspended.
segment.target: Windows provides the background task trigger, DeviceUseTrigger, to let your app perform long running sync and monitoring operations on devices and sensors safely in the background, even if your app is suspended.

segment.source: For more info about app lifecycle, see Launching, resuming, and background tasks.
segment.target: For more info about app lifecycle, see Launching, resuming, and background tasks.

segment.source: For more about background tasks, see Support your app with background tasks.
segment.target: For more about background tasks, see Support your app with background tasks.

segment.source: Note In a Universal Windows app, syncing a device in the background requires that your user has approved background syncing by your app.
segment.target: Note In a Universal Windows app, syncing a device in the background requires that your user has approved background syncing by your app.

segment.source: The device must also be connected to or paired with the PC, with active I/O, and is allowed a maximum of 10 minutes of background activity.
segment.target: The device must also be connected to or paired with the PC, with active I/O, and is allowed a maximum of 10 minutes of background activity.

segment.source: Limitation: critical device operations
segment.target: Limitation: critical device operations

segment.source: Some critical device operations, such as long running firmware updates, cannot be performed with the DeviceUseTrigger.
segment.target: Some critical device operations, such as long running firmware updates, cannot be performed with the DeviceUseTrigger.

segment.source: Such operations can be performed only on the PC, and only by a privileged app that uses the DeviceServicingTrigger.
segment.target: Such operations can be performed only on the PC, and only by a privileged app that uses the DeviceServicingTrigger.

segment.source: A privileged app is an app that the device's manufacturer has authorized to perform those operations.
segment.target: A privileged app is an app that the device's manufacturer has authorized to perform those operations.

segment.source: Device metadata is used to specify which app, if any, has been designated as the privileged app for a device.
segment.target: Device metadata is used to specify which app, if any, has been designated as the privileged app for a device.

segment.source: Your app will perform sync and update operations in code that runs as part of a background task.
segment.target: Your app will perform sync and update operations in code that runs as part of a background task.

segment.source: Introduction to using DeviceUseTrigger
segment.target: Introduction to using DeviceUseTrigger

segment.source: To use the DeviceUseTrigger, follow these basic steps.
segment.target: To use the DeviceUseTrigger, follow these basic steps.

segment.source: For more info about background tasks, see Support your app with background tasks.
segment.target: For more info about background tasks, see Support your app with background tasks.

segment.source: Your app registers its background task in the app manifest and embeds the background task code in a Windows Runtime class that implements IBackgroundTask or in a dedicated JavaScript page for JavaScript apps.
segment.target: Your app registers its background task in the app manifest and embeds the background task code in a Windows Runtime class that implements IBackgroundTask or in a dedicated JavaScript page for JavaScript apps.

segment.source: When your app starts, it will create and configure a trigger object of type DeviceUseTrigger, and store the trigger instance for future use.
segment.target: When your app starts, it will create and configure a trigger object of type DeviceUseTrigger, and store the trigger instance for future use.

segment.source: Your app checks whether the background task has been previously registered and, if not, registers it against the trigger.
segment.target: Your app checks whether the background task has been previously registered and, if not, registers it against the trigger.

segment.source: Note that your app isn't allowed to set conditions on the task associated with this trigger.
segment.target: Note that your app isn't allowed to set conditions on the task associated with this trigger.

segment.source: When your app needs to trigger the background task, it must first call RequestAccessAsync to check if the app is able to request a background task.
segment.target: When your app needs to trigger the background task, it must first call RequestAccessAsync to check if the app is able to request a background task.

segment.source: If the app can request the background task, it calls the RequestAsync activation method on the device trigger object.
segment.target: If the app can request the background task, it calls the RequestAsync activation method on the device trigger object.

segment.source: Your background task isn’t throttled like other system background tasks (there's no CPU time quota) but will run with reduced priority to keep foreground apps responsive.
segment.target: Your background task isn’t throttled like other system background tasks (there's no CPU time quota) but will run with reduced priority to keep foreground apps responsive.

segment.source: Windows will then validate, based on the trigger type, that the necessary policies have been met, including requesting user consent for the operation before starting the background task.
segment.target: Windows will then validate, based on the trigger type, that the necessary policies have been met, including requesting user consent for the operation before starting the background task.

segment.source: Windows monitors system conditions and task runtime and, if necessary, cancels the task if the required conditions are no longer met.
segment.target: Windows monitors system conditions and task runtime and, if necessary, cancels the task if the required conditions are no longer met.

segment.source: When the background tasks reports progress or completion, your app will receive these events through progress and completed events on the registered task.
segment.target: When the background tasks reports progress or completion, your app will receive these events through progress and completed events on the registered task.

segment.source: Frequency and foreground restrictions
segment.target: Frequency and foreground restrictions

segment.source: There is no restriction on the frequency with which your app can initiate operations, but your app can run only one DeviceUseTrigger background task operation at a time (this does not affect other types of background tasks), and can initiate a background task only while your app is in the foreground.
segment.target: There is no restriction on the frequency with which your app can initiate operations, but your app can run only one DeviceUseTrigger background task operation at a time (this does not affect other types of background tasks), and can initiate a background task only while your app is in the foreground.

segment.source: When your app isn't in the foreground, it is unable to initiate a background task with DeviceUseTrigger.
segment.target: When your app isn't in the foreground, it is unable to initiate a background task with DeviceUseTrigger.

segment.source: Your app can't initiate a second DeviceUseTrigger background task before the first background task has completed.
segment.target: Your app can't initiate a second DeviceUseTrigger background task before the first background task has completed.

segment.source: Device restrictions
segment.target: Device restrictions

segment.source: While each app is limited to registering and running only one DeviceUseTrigger background task, the device (on which your app is running) may allow multiple apps to register and run DeviceUseTrigger background tasks.
segment.target: While each app is limited to registering and running only one DeviceUseTrigger background task, the device (on which your app is running) may allow multiple apps to register and run DeviceUseTrigger background tasks.

segment.source: Depending on the device, there may be a limit on the total number of DeviceUseTrigger background tasks from all apps.
segment.target: Depending on the device, there may be a limit on the total number of DeviceUseTrigger background tasks from all apps.

segment.source: This helps preserve battery on resource-constrained devices.
segment.target: This helps preserve battery on resource-constrained devices.

segment.source: Best practices
segment.target: Best practices

segment.source: The following are best practices for apps that use the DeviceUseTrigger background tasks.
segment.target: The following are best practices for apps that use the DeviceUseTrigger background tasks.

segment.source: Programming a background task
segment.target: Programming a background task

segment.source: Using the DeviceUseTrigger background task from your app ensures that any sync or monitoring operations started from your foreground app continue to run in the background if your users switch apps and your foreground app is suspended by Windows.
segment.target: Using the DeviceUseTrigger background task from your app ensures that any sync or monitoring operations started from your foreground app continue to run in the background if your users switch apps and your foreground app is suspended by Windows.

segment.source: We recommend that you follow this overall model for registering, triggering, and unregistering your background tasks:
segment.target: We recommend that you follow this overall model for registering, triggering, and unregistering your background tasks:

segment.source: Call RequestAccessAsync to check if the app is able to request a background task.
segment.target: Call RequestAccessAsync to check if the app is able to request a background task.

segment.source: This must be done before registering a background task.
segment.target: This must be done before registering a background task.

segment.source: Register the background task before requesting the trigger.
segment.target: Register the background task before requesting the trigger.

segment.source: Connect progress and completion event handlers to your trigger.
segment.target: Connect progress and completion event handlers to your trigger.

segment.source: When your app returns from suspension, Windows will provide your app with any queued progress or completion events that can be used to determine the status of your background tasks.
segment.target: When your app returns from suspension, Windows will provide your app with any queued progress or completion events that can be used to determine the status of your background tasks.

segment.source: Close any open device or sensor objects when you trigger your DeviceUseTrigger background task so that those devices or sensors are free to be opened and used by your background task.
segment.target: Close any open device or sensor objects when you trigger your DeviceUseTrigger background task so that those devices or sensors are free to be opened and used by your background task.

segment.source: Register the trigger.
segment.target: Register the trigger.

segment.source: Carefully consider the battery impact of accessing a device or senor from a background task.
segment.target: Carefully consider the battery impact of accessing a device or senor from a background task.

segment.source: For example, having the report interval of a sensor run too frequently could cause the task to run so often that it quickly drains a phone's battery.
segment.target: For example, having the report interval of a sensor run too frequently could cause the task to run so often that it quickly drains a phone's battery.

segment.source: When your background task completes, unregister it.
segment.target: When your background task completes, unregister it.

segment.source: Register for cancellation events from your background task class.
segment.target: Register for cancellation events from your background task class.

segment.source: Registering for cancellation events will allow your background task code to cleanly stop your running background task when canceled by Windows or your foreground app.
segment.target: Registering for cancellation events will allow your background task code to cleanly stop your running background task when canceled by Windows or your foreground app.

segment.source: On app exit (not suspension), unregister and cancel any running tasks if your app no longer needs them.
segment.target: On app exit (not suspension), unregister and cancel any running tasks if your app no longer needs them.

segment.source: On resource-constrained systems, such as low-memory phones, this will allow other apps to use a DeviceUseTrigger background task.
segment.target: On resource-constrained systems, such as low-memory phones, this will allow other apps to use a DeviceUseTrigger background task.

segment.source: When your app exits, unregister and cancel any running tasks.
segment.target: When your app exits, unregister and cancel any running tasks.

segment.source: When your app exits, your background tasks will be canceled and any existing event handlers will be disconnected from your existing background tasks.
segment.target: When your app exits, your background tasks will be canceled and any existing event handlers will be disconnected from your existing background tasks.

segment.source: This prevents you from determining the state of your background tasks.
segment.target: This prevents you from determining the state of your background tasks.

segment.source: Unregistering and canceling the background task will allow your cancellation code to cleanly stop your background tasks.
segment.target: Unregistering and canceling the background task will allow your cancellation code to cleanly stop your background tasks.

segment.source: Cancelling a background task
segment.target: Cancelling a background task

segment.source: To cancel a task running in the background from your foreground app, use the Unregister method on the BackgroundTaskRegistration object you use in your app to register the DeviceUseTrigger background task.
segment.target: To cancel a task running in the background from your foreground app, use the Unregister method on the BackgroundTaskRegistration object you use in your app to register the DeviceUseTrigger background task.

segment.source: Unregistering your background task by using the Unregister method on BackgroundTaskRegistration will cause the background task infrastructure to cancel your background task.
segment.target: Unregistering your background task by using the Unregister method on BackgroundTaskRegistration will cause the background task infrastructure to cancel your background task.

segment.source: The Unregister method additionally takes a Boolean true or false value to indicate if currently running instances of your background task should be canceled without allowing them to finish.
segment.target: The Unregister method additionally takes a Boolean true or false value to indicate if currently running instances of your background task should be canceled without allowing them to finish.

segment.source: For more info, see the API reference for Unregister.
segment.target: For more info, see the API reference for Unregister.

segment.source: In addition to Unregister, your app will also need to call BackgroundTaskDeferral.Complete.
segment.target: In addition to Unregister, your app will also need to call BackgroundTaskDeferral.Complete.

segment.source: This informs the system that the asynchronous operation associated with a background task has finished.
segment.target: This informs the system that the asynchronous operation associated with a background task has finished.
